rule.description: OAT: OAT Base Rules for Endpoint Logs
OAT: OAT Detection Events
OAT: OAT emailActivityData Events
OAT: Suspicious office document behavior execution detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects potential malicious behavior where Microsoft Office applications (Word, Excel) attempt to spawn executable files. This pattern is commonly associated with macro-enabled documents being used to execute malware or other unauthorized code.

rule.description: OAT: Unauthorized screen capture activity detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects potential screen capture attempts using Windows graphic libraries (user32.dll, gdi32.dll) by suspicious processes. This behavior is commonly associated with information gathering and data theft attempts where attackers try to capture sensitive information from the user's screen.

rule.description: OAT: Encryption command line parameters with suspicious arguments detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects the use of specific command-line parameters commonly associated with encryption tools. These parameters, particularly those specifying paths and encryption settings, may indicate attempts to encrypt files or network shares for malicious purposes.

rule.description: OAT: Unix - Ftp Connection Establised Event
OAT: Netcat Listener on Port 80
OAT: PowerView.ps1 Suspicious Download and Temp Folder Drop
OAT: Execution of PowerShell Module from Temp Folder
OAT: Execution of Minidump Module via rundll32.exe for lsass.exe Extraction
OAT: Detection of File Compression Using 7zip
OAT: Delete System logs using wevutil command
OAT: Delete Security logs using wevutil command

OAT: modified_process_create_remotethread

OAT: modified_process_write_process
OAT: modified_process_read_process
OAT: modified_write_processname

OAT: windows_hook_set

OAT: bm_invoke
OAT: bm_invoke_api
OAT: Potentially malicious file creation with known malware patterns detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies the creation of files matching known malicious patterns, including template files and specific executables. These file patterns are often associated with malware distribution and execution attempts, particularly through malicious document templates and executables.

rule.description: OAT: Dropping Of File In Startup Folder.
OAT: Net Use Shared Resource Mapping Detected.
OAT: Modification of the hosts file.
OAT: Unusual Outbound Winlogon Connection on Non-Standard Port
OAT: Creation of Local Account via Net.exe
OAT: Suspicious VB Script Execution from User's Download Path.
OAT: Suspicious VBS script download detected in Chrome
OAT: Possible Security-Related Program Uninstallation via WMIC Detected.
OAT: Attempted execution attribute modification via Chmod command detected.
OAT: User attempted sudo command enumeration on endpoint
OAT: Executable Script Execution from Startup Folder
OAT: System Reboot Via Command Line
OAT: File Transfer Via SCP
OAT: Failed Logon Windows Event
OAT: Windows Account Created

rule.field: Identified Creation Of Domain Account In Active Directory
rule.description: OAT: $(filters_0_name)
OAT: IFFCOADMIN User Creation Event Detected.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that a user account named IFFCOADMIN has been created within the OAT system. This event is crucial for tracking and auditing administrative user account activities.

rule.description: OAT: User creation event detected by IFFCOADMIN.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that a user account by IFFCOADMIN has been created within the OAT system. This event is crucial for tracking and auditing administrative user account activities.

rule.description: OAT: Possible Privilege Escalation using sudo su
OAT: WMI-based User Enumeration for Targeted Reconnaissance
OAT: Third-Party Printer Driver/Config Execution
rule.info: Description: This alert triggers when a third-party printer driver or configuration file is executed from the Windows driver store. This activity could indicate an attempt to exploit printer driver vulnerabilities for privilege escalation or defense evasion.

rule.description: OAT: System Owner User Group Discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert is triggered when an attempt is made to enumerate user groups using the whoami command. This could indicate reconnaissance activity where an attacker is gathering information about user permissions and access levels.

rule.description: OAT: AMSI Detection of Suspicious PowerShell Parameters
rule.info: Description: This alert is generated when PowerShell is executed with parameters commonly used to bypass security controls (noninteractive, noprofile). These parameters are often used by attackers to evade detection and execute malicious commands.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious PowerShell Parameters Execution
rule.info: Description: This alert detects PowerShell execution with suspicious parameters like noprofile and noninteractive. These parameters are commonly used in malicious PowerShell scripts to avoid detection and bypass security controls by preventing profile loading and user interaction.

rule.description: OAT: Show Mapped Drives and Devices
rule.info: Description: This alert triggers when a user lists mapped network drives using the 'net use' command. While this can be legitimate activity, it may also indicate network discovery attempts by attackers trying to identify available network resources and potential lateral movement paths.

rule.description: OAT: WMI Security Software Discovery - AV
rule.info: Description: This alert is generated when WMI commands are used to query information about installed antivirus products. This type of reconnaissance is commonly performed by attackers to identify security measures in place and potential ways to evade them.

rule.description: OAT: Network Share Removal Using NET Utility
rule.info: Description: This alert indicates the deletion of a network share using the NET command. While this can be legitimate administrative activity, it may also represent an attempt to remove evidence of network access or disrupt network resource availability.

rule.description: OAT: Attempt to Read Unix Shadow File Detection
rule.info: Description: This alert is triggered when there's an attempt to access the /etc/shadow file, which contains encrypted password hashes on Unix systems. Such access attempts often indicate credential harvesting or privilege escalation attempts, as this file should only be accessible by privileged users.

rule.description: OAT: View file contents using 'cat' command.
rule.info: Description: The `cat` command being monitored could indicate attempts to read sensitive system files or configuration information. While commonly used for legitimate purposes, it can also be used by attackers to gather system information or access sensitive data files.

rule.description: OAT: Discovery of Files Using Mtab
rule.info: Description: This alert triggers when someone accesses the /etc/mtab file, which contains information about mounted filesystems. Attackers may use this information during reconnaissance to understand the system's storage configuration and identify potential targets for data theft or persistence.

rule.description: OAT: Discovering Linux System Network Configuration Using Cat
rule.info: Description: This alert is triggered when someone attempts to read the /etc/hosts file. While this can be legitimate system administration activity, it may also indicate reconnaissance efforts to map network configurations and identify potential targets for lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Attempt to Read Unix Password File Detection
rule.info: Description: This alert triggers when there's an attempt to read the /etc/passwd file. While this file is readable by all users, attempts to access it may indicate reconnaissance activity to enumerate system users or preparation for password cracking attempts.

rule.description: OAT: OS Information Discovery Attempt using uname
rule.info: Description: This alert indicates an attempt to gather detailed operating system information using the uname command. This type of system information gathering is often part of reconnaissance activities to identify system vulnerabilities and plan further attacks.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of a command using the source command in Bash.
rule.info: Description: This alert is triggered when commands are executed using the source command in Bash. While this can be legitimate, it may indicate attempts to load and execute malicious scripts or commands, potentially bypassing certain security controls.

rule.description: OAT: Viewing Scheduled Jobs with Crontab
rule.info: Description: This alert is triggered when someone lists scheduled crontab jobs. While this is a common administrative task, unauthorized access to crontab information could indicate reconnaissance for persistence mechanisms or attempts to identify scheduled maintenance windows for exploitation.

rule.description: OAT: Data Compression with 'zip' Command.
rule.info: Description: This alert indicates use of the zip command with verbose output. While data compression is common, it could also indicate potential data staging before exfiltration, particularly when combined with other suspicious activities or occurring at unusual times.

rule.description: OAT: Command Shell Invocation for Hostname Retrieval
rule.info: Description: This alert triggers when the hostname command is executed through cmd.exe. While this is a basic system command, it's often used during the reconnaissance phase of an attack to gather system information and could indicate the early stages of lateral movement or network mapping.

rule.description: OAT: Group policy discovery using gpresult
rule.info: Description: This alert indicates that the gpresult command was executed. It is commonly used to retrieve group policies applied to a system and may signify reconnaissance activity.

rule.description: OAT: Registry modification: system policies - uac elevation
rule.info: Description: The alert triggers when UAC policies are modified through registry keys. Such changes can indicate privilege escalation attempts.

rule.description: OAT: Schedule task creation detected
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the creation of scheduled tasks, which can be used for persistence or privilege escalation by malicious actors.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of a scheduled task by a process
rule.info: Description: The execution of a scheduled task by taskeng.exe can signify malicious task scheduling for persistence or privilege escalation.

rule.description: OAT: Local account creation using net.exe
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies the use of the net.exe command to create new local user accounts, which may be used for persistence or unauthorized access.

rule.description: OAT: Add accounts in remote desktop users group
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the addition of accounts to the Remote Desktop Users group, which can enable unauthorized remote access.

rule.description: OAT: Setting file attribute to hidden via attrib.exe
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the attrib command to hide files, a common technique for evading detection.

rule.description: OAT: Wscript or cscript execution detection
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the execution of wscript or cscript to execute VBScript files, which may be used for script-based malware delivery.

rule.description: OAT: Wsl execution detection
rule.info: Description: This alert detects execution of WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux), which may be used for evasion or running unauthorized Linux-based tools on Windows.

rule.description: OAT: Web shell via xcopy
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of xcopy to deploy web shells or transfer malicious files, which may indicate persistence or lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: User discovery using who command
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the who command to enumerate logged-in users on a Linux system, which is commonly seen during reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Unix password change event detection
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of the passwd command to change passwords, which could indicate credential manipulation or privilege escalation.

rule.description: OAT: Display network connections using netstat
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of the netstat command to display active network connections, which can be part of reconnaissance activities.

rule.description: OAT: Iso file creation
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the creation of ISO files, which can be used to stage and deliver malicious payloads.

rule.description: OAT: Sethc execution using winlogon
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of sethc.exe with winlogon.exe, a technique often used for persistence or privilege escalation on Windows systems.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of ping command
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the execution of the ping command, often used to check network connectivity as part of reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of product uninstallation via msiexec
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of msiexec.exe to uninstall products, which may be part of a defense evasion technique.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of product installation via msiexec
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the execution of msiexec.exe to install products, which can be used for persistence or unauthorized installations.

rule.description: OAT: Enabling service using systemctl
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of systemctl to enable services on Linux systems, which can be used for persistence.

rule.description: OAT: Information discovery via uptime
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the uptime command, which may be used to gather system availability information.

rule.description: OAT: Outbound connection using putty
rule.info: Description: This alert detects outbound connections made using Putty, which may indicate unauthorized remote access or command and control activity.

rule.description: OAT: Gpscript logon script execution
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the execution of Gpscript logon scripts, which may be leveraged for malicious activity during system startup.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of bash from cron
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the execution of bash scripts triggered from cron jobs, which may be used for scheduled malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Directory enumeration using lsof command
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the lsof command to enumerate files and directories, which may indicate reconnaissance or discovery activity.

rule.description: OAT: Termination of process
rule.info: Description: This alert detects forceful termination of processes using taskkill, which may indicate malicious activity to disable security tools.

rule.description: OAT: Linux CPU info discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies attempts to gather CPU information via the /proc/cpuinfo file, commonly used for system discovery.

rule.description: OAT: Linux list kernel modules
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to list kernel modules using the lsmod command, which can be part of system reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Enumerate network connections using ARP
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies attempts to enumerate network connections using the ARP command, which may indicate network reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: System hardware discovery via WMI
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of WMI commands to retrieve hardware manufacturer information, commonly seen in reconnaissance activities.

rule.description: OAT: Process discovery via top command
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of the top command to discover active processes, which may indicate reconnaissance or monitoring activity.

rule.description: OAT: Display disk information using WMIC
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of WMIC to retrieve disk information, which can be part of system discovery activities.

rule.description: OAT: Distribution release information discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to retrieve Linux distribution release information using the cat command.

rule.description: OAT: Driver installation via pnputil.exe
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of pnputil.exe to install drivers, which may be used for persistence or malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Creation of suspect driver file in windows directory
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the creation of suspicious driver files in the Windows directory, which may indicate defense evasion techniques.

rule.description: OAT: Gets the status information of a process via cat
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies attempts to gather process status information using the cat command on Linux systems.

rule.description: OAT: Unix hostname discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the hostname command to identify system names on Unix-like systems.

rule.description: OAT: Unix environment variables discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to list environment variables in Unix-like systems using the 'env' command. Such behavior is often seen during reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Upload file to external website via curl
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of 'curl' to upload files to external websites using POST requests. It may indicate data exfiltration activities.

rule.description: OAT: Detects unusual LDAP protocol in command line
rule.info: Description: This alert detects LDAP protocol usage via command line, which can indicate reconnaissance or unauthorized directory access attempts.

rule.description: OAT: Account discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to enumerate user accounts on Windows domains using the 'net user /domain' command. This behavior is often associated with reconnaissance or lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Account Discovery on Domain Controller
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to discover user accounts on domain controllers using 'net user /domain'. This behavior may indicate reconnaissance activity.

rule.description: OAT: Monitor Active Directory Router Layer DLL for anomalies
rule.info: Description: This alert monitors for anomalies in the Active Directory Router Layer DLL, which may indicate tampering or malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Detect AutoStart execution via Active Setup
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of Active Setup registry entries for persistence. Active Setup can be abused to execute scripts or programs at user logon.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious auto-start entries in registry
rule.info: Description: This alert detects suspicious auto-start registry entries that may be used for persistence or malicious activity during system startup.

rule.description: OAT: Detect AWS credentials exposed via grep command
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to search for AWS credentials using 'grep', which may expose sensitive information.

rule.description: OAT: Detect CPU properties discovery via WMI
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of WMI commands to gather CPU property details, commonly used for system reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Placing executable file in application data and temporary directory
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the placement of executable files in the Temp or AppData directories, which are commonly abused for malicious persistence.

rule.description: OAT: String encryption/compression via command line
rule.info: Description: This alert detects encrypted or compressed strings passed to executables in the Windows web folder via the command line.

rule.description: OAT: Executing remote payload via msiexec
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies the use of msiexec to execute a remote payload, leveraging the Windows Installer for unauthorized execution.

rule.description: OAT: External retrieval through curl or wget
rule.info: Description: This alert detects external file downloads using curl or wget, commonly used for transferring data or malicious payloads.

rule.description: OAT: Downloading a file using curl or wget on macOS
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies attempts to download files using curl or wget on macOS systems, which may indicate file transfer or payload retrieval.

rule.description: OAT: Recycle bin file creation
rule.info: Description: This alert detects file creation in the recycle bin, which is often used by adversaries to hide files or stage data.

rule.description: OAT: Adding firewall rule via netsh
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to add firewall rules using netsh, which may be used to bypass security controls.

rule.description: OAT: Running bash shell script with java
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the execution of bash shell scripts via java, which may indicate malicious script execution.

rule.description: OAT: Executing commands in ms office applications using dde
rule.info: Description: This alert detects command execution using dynamic data exchange (dde) in microsoft office, a technique used for malicious payload execution.

rule.description: OAT: Windows shell spawned by mshta
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies mshta spawning a windows shell, often seen in script-based attacks to bypass security controls.

rule.description: OAT: Establishing persistence through windows autorun registry key
rule.info: Description: This alert detects persistence mechanisms established via windows autoruns registry keys, often abused by malware.

rule.description: OAT: A binary executable was created in the windows folder
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the creation of dll files in the windows folder, a technique often used for persistence or code injection.

rule.description: OAT: Potential access of malicious office add-ins
rule.info: Description: The alert detects access to potentially malicious Microsoft Office add-ins located in the roaming folder.

rule.description: OAT: Discovering process information using wmi
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of WMI to gather process-related information, which can be used for reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Silent execution of regsvr32
rule.info: Description: This alert detects silent execution of Regsvr32 to run DLL or executable files, a common proxy execution technique.

rule.description: OAT: Silent execution of regsvr32 on localappdata path
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the execution of Regsvr32 on LocalAppData files, a technique often used for defense evasion.

rule.description: OAT: Potentially malicious execution of mofcomp file
rule.info: Description: This alert detects execution of MOFCOMP files, which can be used to execute malicious scripts on Windows systems.

rule.description: OAT: Assuming ownership using the takeown utility
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the use of the Takeown utility to take ownership of files, which can be used for permission modification.

rule.description: OAT: Discovery of system network configuration
rule.info: Description: This alert detects attempts to discover system network configurations using netsh commands.

rule.description: OAT: Discovery of system files using net.exe
rule.info: Description: This alert detects the discovery of system files using Net.exe commands.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious msdt execution
OAT: Suspicious connection to domain/ip from microsoft office
OAT: Executing commands via ssh command line
OAT: Running shell scripts using python executor arguments on linux
OAT: Stopping a service using net command or service controller
OAT: Executing services through the service control manager
OAT: Discovering services using command line
OAT: Creating scheduled tasks through processes
OAT: Execution of services
OAT: Detect creation/execution of scheduled task
OAT: Discover sandbox execution via system information
OAT: Remote system discovered through ping
OAT: Registry shell spawning persistence
OAT: Registry query via reg.exe
OAT: Process discovery via psutil
OAT: Process discovery via ps command

OAT: Powershell encoded command execution

OAT: Suspected remote file copy via shared folder
OAT: Possible cryptocurrency mining
OAT: Concealing files using the mv command
OAT: Running the "wget" command
OAT: Modifying the crontab file
OAT: Start the cron service

OAT: Create a hidden file or directory linux
OAT: Compile application - unix

OAT: Change system wallpaper
OAT: Lesser-known PowerShell parameters utilized in command lines
OAT: Unexpected connection of monitored binary files
OAT: IIS - Executing any .exe file
OAT: Executing commands indirectly using conhost.exe
OAT: Testing internet connection to popular websites
OAT: DLL providing LDAP services
OAT: Compressing data in linux using gzip
OAT: Downloading internally using curl or wget
OAT: Compressing data using tar command
rule.info: Description: Tar command compressing data may be used for archiving files, potentially indicating preparation for exfiltration.

rule.description: OAT: Discovering linux system services using systemctl
rule.info: Description: The "systemctl" command is used to list active system services, which can indicate system reconnaissance activity.

rule.description: OAT: Loading arbitrary DLLs via wuauclt
rule.info: Description: The "wuauclt.exe" process is being used to load arbitrary DLLs, potentially indicating malicious behavior.

rule.description: OAT: Loading of kerberos DLL
rule.info: Description: Detects the loading of Kerberos DLL files, which may indicate credential theft or impersonation attempts.

rule.description: OAT: Discovering logged-in users using the "users" command
rule.info: Description: Detects attempts to discover logged-in users on Linux systems, which can indicate reconnaissance activities.

rule.description: OAT: Outbound SSH connections
rule.info: Description: Detects outbound SSH connections, which may be used for remote access or lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Ping execution for remote system discovery
rule.info: Description: The "ping" command is used to check remote systems' availability, often during reconnaissance activities.

rule.description: OAT: Performing a telnet port scan.
rule.info: Description: Telnet is being used to scan network ports, which may indicate reconnaissance activities.

rule.description: OAT: Test the file write permission by using the "test" command.
rule.info: Description: The "test" command is used to check file write permissions, which can indicate permission probing.

rule.description: OAT: Process discovery
rule.info: Description: The "tasklist" command is executed to enumerate running processes, which may indicate reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Setting up a reverse SOCKS proxy using SSH on Linux.
rule.info: Description: SSH is being used to set up a reverse SOCKS proxy, which can indicate lateral movement or persistence.

rule.description: OAT: Extract specific patterns from process memory.
rule.info: Description: Detects memory scraping activities where process memory contents are dumped to files.

rule.description: OAT: Executing shell commands through HTTPD.
rule.info: Description: Detects shell execution via HTTPD, which may indicate a compromised web server running malicious commands.

rule.description: OAT: System information discovery via systeminfo
rule.info: Description: The "systeminfo" command retrieves system details, often used for reconnaissance on Windows hosts.

rule.description: OAT: Find command was used to list files.
rule.info: Description: The "find" command is executed to list files, which may indicate reconnaissance or data discovery.

rule.description: OAT: Files and directories using the grep command.
rule.info: Description: The "grep" command searches for files and directories, indicating possible file reconnaissance.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of InstallUtil utility
rule.info: Description: Detects execution of the InstallUtil utility, commonly abused for bypassing security controls and running malicious payloads.

rule.description: OAT: A document has been opened in endpoint via email application
rule.info: Description: A document attachment has been opened via Microsoft Office email application, indicating potential phishing or suspicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Execute Arbitrary DLL Via Msiexec
rule.info: Description: Msiexec.exe was used to execute an arbitrary DLL file, potentially bypassing security mechanisms.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of Commands Using Trap Signals
rule.info: Description: A command was executed using the "trap" signal, which may be used to maintain persistence on the system.

rule.description: OAT: A visible directory is created
rule.info: Description: A visible directory was created, which could indicate an attempt to manipulate or hide files in plain sight.

rule.description: OAT: Compressing Data Using Command Line
rule.info: Description: Data compression was performed using the "7za.exe" command-line utility, which is often used for archiving files.

rule.description: OAT: Disabling Security-Related Services
rule.info: Description: A service was stopped using the systemctl command, potentially targeting security-related services to evade detection.

rule.description: OAT: Placing a PE File in an Unusual Directory Using a Remote Access Tool
rule.info: Description: A PE file was placed in an uncommon directory using a remote access tool, which could indicate malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: PDF file creation comes from known email applications
rule.info: Description: A PDF file was created from a known email application, potentially indicating a phishing attempt.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious outbound RDP connections detected
rule.info: Description: Detected outbound RDP connections initiated using mstsc, potentially indicating lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: A PowerShell command to enumerate network shares was detected.

rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that user IFFCOADMIN has modified privileges. This event is essential for monitoring privilege escalation and related security policies.

rule.description: OAT: Abnormal file encryption activity detected
rule.info: Description: This rule detects abnormal file encryption activity by identifying file extensions commonly associated with ransomware (.lock, .cry, .encrypted). These indicators signal unauthorized encryption attempts targeting data for impact.

rule.description: OAT: Unusual process execution detected
rule.info: Description: This rule monitors for anomalous or suspicious process executions within the environment. It is triggered when a process is launched that deviates from the established baseline of normal system behavior, user activity, or application execution patterns. The goal is to detect potential indicators of compromise (IoCs), including malware execution, unauthorized software, or abnormal behavior that could signify a security threat.

OAT: $(filters_0_name)
OAT: Parent process detected, suspicious processes identified.
rule.info: Description: The rule detects suspicious parent processes like calc.exe, notepad.exe, and others commonly used for malicious activities. These processes may indicate an escalation of privilege or lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: $(process_name) process detected.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates the presence of regsvr32.exe or rundll32.exe processes, which are commonly used by attackers to execute malicious payloads or perform DLL hijacking. Monitoring these processes helps identify suspicious or malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: $(ChildProcessName) process detected.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that a user account by IFFCOADMIN has been deleted within the OAT system. This event is crucial for tracking and auditing administrative user account activities.

rule.description: OAT: An attempt was made to access or modify a registry object.
rule.info: Description: This rule monitors registry value modifications (4657) and registry key access attempts (4663). Such activities may indicate unauthorized access, malicious tampering, or persistence mechanisms by attackers.

rule.description: OAT: $(image) process detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects the execution of processes such as notepad.exe, calc.exe, or mspaint.exe, which are often exploited or mimicked by attackers to perform malicious actions while blending into legitimate activities.

rule.description: OAT: $(process_name) process detected.
rule.info: Description: Detects persistence mechanisms targeting sensitive processes such as lsass.exe or svchost.exe to exploit network services on non-standard ports.

rule.description: OAT: Potential Meterpreter network activity detection.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects suspicious outbound connections that attempt to reach non-standard ports or external IPs, potentially bypassing firewalls. This behavior could indicate malicious activities like data exfiltration or unauthorized communication.

rule.description: OAT: SAM access event detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects access attempts to the SAM (Security Accounts Manager) database, which is crucial for tracking potential changes or deletions of user accounts and auditing administrative activities within the system.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious privilege manipulation for impersonation detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects attempts to manipulate security tokens for impersonation privileges. Such activities could indicate attempts to escalate privileges or impersonate other users, which is commonly used in privilege escalation attacks.

rule.description: OAT: Meterpreter credential access detection.
OAT: Suspicious file system activities detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects suspicious file system activities, such as the presence of executable files in temporary or application data folders, which may indicate malicious activity or persistence mechanisms.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious keylogger activities detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects suspicious activities indicating the potential presence of keyloggers, such as the capture of keystrokes or screenshots by processes like explorer.exe or svchost.exe.

rule.description: OAT: Potential Meterpreter file system activity detection.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies suspicious file system artifacts that do not reside in common system directories, indicating potential malicious files or persistence techniques.

rule.description: OAT: Meterpreter process injection detection.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies process injection attempts, which are a common tactic used in advanced attacks to execute payloads within legitimate processes, thereby evading detection.

rule.description: OAT: Windows service and policy modification detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects Windows event logs indicating changes to system services, security policies, or system time settings. Such modifications could indicate attempts to bypass security controls or establish persistence.

rule.description: OAT: Shell command execution with suspicious pattern observed.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects the execution of shell commands that may indicate attempts to run unauthorized scripts or commands. Such activities could be associated with attempts to establish persistence or execute malicious code through command shell interfaces.

rule.description: OAT: File renaming and suspicious process execution.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects suspicious file renaming and execution activities. Such patterns are indicative of attempts to evade detection and establish persistence.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious command execution with file redirection.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects command patterns associated with malware behavior, including system reconnaissance, file manipulation in temp directories, and attempts to establish persistence through system services and administrative groups. These patterns are commonly observed in malware that attempts to gather system information and maintain access.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious command execution with file redirection detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies patterns associated with systematic system enumeration and information gathering activities. The sequence includes discovery of system configurations, file system mapping, and execution of multiple discovery commands, which may indicate a coordinated reconnaissance effort.

rule.description: OAT: Potential malicious activity detected involving unauthorized screen capture, malware-patterned file creation, or suspicious Office document behavior.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects potential screen capture attempts using Windows graphic libraries (user32.dll, gdi32.dll) by suspicious processes. This behavior is commonly associated with information gathering and data theft attempts where attackers try to capture sensitive information from the user's screen.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious email attachment with executable content detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects incoming emails containing potentially malicious attachments with executable extensions (exe, dll, cab). These file types are commonly used in phishing campaigns to deliver malware.

rule.description: OAT: Malicious file pattern match detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects files matching known malicious patterns based on specific file names and extensions. These patterns are associated with malware that attempts to masquerade as legitimate system or application files.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious DLL loading through system utility detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies potentially malicious DLL loading through rundll32.exe with suspicious parent process relationships. This technique is commonly used to bypass security controls by abusing legitimate Windows utilities for malicious code execution.

rule.description: OAT: System restore point deletion activity observed.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects attempts to delete Windows Volume Shadow Copy backups using various methods including WMIC, vssadmin, or PowerShell commands. This activity is commonly associated with ransomware preparation to prevent system recovery.

rule.description: Known credential extraction tools execution detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies the execution of tools commonly associated with credential harvesting and password extraction. These utilities are frequently used in post-exploitation phases to gather authentication credentials from system memory and files.

rule.description: LSASS credential dumping behavior detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects attempts to access or dump memory from the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) process. This behavior is commonly associated with attempts to extract cached credentials and authentication data from system memory.

rule.description: OAT: credential extraction tool and memory dumping detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies the combined occurrence of credential extraction tools and LSASS memory dumping activities. This pattern suggests a coordinated attempt to harvest credentials using multiple methods, which is a common tactic in privilege escalation and lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Ransomware-related file pattern extension modification detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects file modification patterns commonly associated with ransomware activity, specifically looking for changes in file extensions and creation of ransom notes. This behavior indicates active file encryption and system compromise phases of a ransomware attack.

rule.description: OAT: Data transfer utility execution detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects the execution of file transfer and synchronization tools that could be used for data exfiltration. While these tools have legitimate uses, they are commonly abused to transfer large amounts of data to external locations during data theft attempts.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple windows account created.
Detection of unauthorized Deep Security agent service removal
rule.info: Description : This security detection rule monitors for unauthorized attempts to remove or delete the Deep Security Agent service (ds_nuagent) on Windows systems. The rule specifically watches for the execution of 'sc.exe' commands targeting the ds_nuagent service, which is a critical security component responsible for endpoint protection. It employs case-insensitive regular expressions to capture various command patterns that could be used to delete the service, including both quoted and unquoted service name variations. By monitoring these specific command patterns, the rule helps identify potential security compromises where attackers or unauthorized users might attempt to disable endpoint security by removing the Deep Security Agent service. This detection is crucial for maintaining the integrity of endpoint security controls and can serve as an early warning system for potential security breaches. The rule is specifically targeted at Windows environments where the Deep Security Agent is deployed, helping security teams respond quickly to unauthorized modification attempts of critical security infrastructure.

rule.description: OAT: Restore Point deletion and encryption activity detected.
rule.info: 106790: OAT: Encryption command line parameters with suspicious arguments detected. 106458: OAT: System restore point deletion activity observed. Description: This correlation rule identifies a sequence of events indicating potential ransomware activity, where encryption commands are followed by attempts to remove system recovery capabilities. This pattern is commonly observed in the early stages of ransomware deployment.

rule.description: OAT: Credential capture activity followed by persistence mechanism detected.
rule.info: 106767: OAT: Suspicious keylogger activities detected. 106178: Establishing persistence through windows autorun registry key. Description: This correlation rule identifies a sequence where potential keylogging activity is followed by registry modifications for persistence. This pattern indicates possible post-compromise activity to maintain access while gathering credentials.

rule.description: OAT: Potential Brute Force Attempt via Net Use for Shared Resource Mapping.
OAT: Multiple Suspicious VB Script Execution from User's Download Path.
rule.info: Description: Multiple suspicious VBScript executions from a user's download path within 60 seconds and at a frequency of 5 occurrences could indicate a malware infection or automated attack. This behavior often suggests an attempt to execute malicious scripts rapidly, potentially compromising the system. Immediate investigation and remediation are essential to prevent further damage and secure the system.

rule.description: OAT: Potential Suspicious Activity: VB Script Download and Execution
OAT: Multiple files being dropped into the startup folder.
OAT: Potentially Suspicious Script Detected and Executed in Startup Folder.
OAT: Post-Reboot Startup Script Execution
OAT: Multiple Login Failure Detection within a minute
OAT: Potential Brute Force Login Attempt Detected.
OAT: High Number of User Windows Account Created
OAT: User Creation and Login failure Event.
OAT: Multiple Time Possible Privilege Escalation using sudo su
OAT: File enumeration attempt followed by access to sensitive unix files.
rule.info: Description: The alert was triggered by a suspicious attempt to view file contents using the 'cat' command, followed by an attempt to access the Unix shadow file. Accessing this file can indicate malicious intent, often tied to credential harvesting or privilege escalation attempts in Unix-based systems.

rule.description: OAT: Execution of command via source in bash followed by OS information discovery using uname.
rule.info: Description: This rule is triggered when a command is executed via the source command in Bash, followed by the use of uname for system information discovery. This sequence suggests a potential malicious script execution, immediately followed by reconnaissance to gather OS details, which attackers often do to tailor further exploitation.

rule.description: OAT: Executing Bash Commands and Listing Crontab Jobs
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule detects a pattern of bash command execution followed by crontab enumeration. This sequence of events could indicate an attacker exploring system scheduling capabilities after gaining initial access, possibly preparing to establish persistence through scheduled tasks.

rule.description: OAT: Creation and execution of schedule-task
rule.info: Description: This rule detects the creation and execution of scheduled tasks, combining two key events that may indicate malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Creating accounts and adding users to remote desktop users group
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule identifies the creation of accounts followed by their addition to the Remote Desktop Users group, often used for unauthorized remote access.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple file attribute to hidden via attrib.exe
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies multiple uses of the attrib command to hide files in a short timeframe, potentially indicating malicious activity to evade detection.

rule.description: OAT: User discovery followed by password change event on unix
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule detects user discovery attempts followed by password changes on a Unix system, which may indicate credential compromise or lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple time enabling service using systemctl
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies multiple attempts to enable services on a Linux system using systemctl, which may indicate persistent or malicious activity.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple outbound connection using putty
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies multiple outbound connections using Putty within a short timeframe, which may indicate persistent or malicious remote access.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple shortcut file creation in startup folder
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies multiple shortcut files created in the Windows Startup folder, indicating potential persistence mechanisms.

rule.description: OAT: Suspicious command execution followed by system information discovery
rule.info: Description: This alert correlates suspicious command execution followed by CPU information discovery, indicating possible reconnaissance or exploitation.

rule.description: OAT: Pnputil.exe usage coinciding with suspicious driver file creation
rule.info: Description: This alert correlates driver installation via pnputil.exe with the creation of suspicious driver files in the Windows directory.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple suspicious auto-start entries in registry
rule.info: Description: This alert identifies multiple suspicious auto-start registry entries within a short timeframe, indicating potential malicious persistence mechanisms.

rule.description: OAT: Binary executable created with persistence via windows autorun registry key
rule.info: Description: The alert detects a binary executable created with persistence through the Windows autorun registry key.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple suspicious connection to domain/ip from microsoft office
OAT: Multiple time ssh command line execution
OAT: Executing multiple shell scripts using python executor arguments on linux
OAT: Multiple time powershell outbound connection
OAT: Encoded powershell command preceding registry modification
OAT: Potential spear phishing attachments occurring multiple times with archive file
OAT: Potential copying of multiple files remotely via a shared folder
OAT: Suspicious file download using wget followed by file concealment via mv command
rule.info: Description: The alert was triggered by the execution of the 'wget' command to download files, followed by the 'mv' command to conceal or move files. Such behavior is often indicative of malicious file transfer activities where the attacker attempts to download tools or malware and hide traces of the operation by renaming or moving files.

rule.description: OAT: Crontab file edited and restart
OAT: Create hidden multiple files or directories in linux
OAT: Disabling multiple services via the registry
OAT: Change system wallpaper and disable a service through the registry
OAT: Data compression followed by internal file download detected.
rule.info: Description: GZip command compressing data followed by an internal file download could indicate preparation for data exfiltration or unauthorized file transfer.

rule.description: OAT: Data compression using tar command followed by internal file download detected.
rule.info: Description: A tar command compressing data followed by an internal file download indicates possible exfiltration or malicious file transfer.

rule.description: OAT: Repeated outbound SSH connections.
OAT: Executing multiple document attachments via email application.
rule.info: Description: Multiple document attachments were executed through an email application in a short timeframe, indicating potential phishing attacks.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple time Disabling Security-Related Services
rule.info: Description: Multiple attempts to stop security-related services were detected within a short timeframe, indicating evasion tactics.

rule.description: OAT: Dropping multiple PE files into an uncommon directory using a remote access tool
rule.info: Description: Multiple PE files were dropped into an uncommon directory using a remote access tool, which may indicate persistent lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Repeated Suspicious outbound RDP connections detected
rule.info: Description: Multiple outbound RDP connections were detected within a short timeframe, potentially indicating unauthorized remote access.

rule.description: OAT: The group policy on an endpoint was forcibly updated using the gpupdate force parameter.
OAT: Deleting multiple Windows services.
OAT: Deleting multiple Scheduled Tasks.
OAT: Multiple instances of creating hidden directories.
OAT: Multiple files copied from a remote machine
OAT: A successful logon from impersonated account.
OAT: Multiple Files Copy Over Administrative Share via Copy Command
OAT: Multiple potentially suspicious changes to a Windows service.
OAT: Multiple executions in a non-executable folder.
OAT: Multiple instances of potential copying of malicious Office add-ins
OAT: Multiple Suspicious Outbound Connections using Postman
OAT: Multiple instances of suspicious user account bypass using PowerShell
OAT: Multiple instances of accessing credentials via PasswordVault
OAT: Suspicious execution of Multiple executable files through MSHTA
OAT: Multiple time Registry has been Edited from Screensaver
OAT: Multiple Unknown File Creation Through Spearphishing Attachment
OAT: Multiple Instances of Unknown File Creation Via Spearphishing Attachments
OAT: Multiple instances of hidden directory creation on Mac systems
OAT: Exploit Public-Facing Application leads to Command-and-Control communication.
OAT: Unix - FTP Connection Established and File Import Event Detected
OAT: Unix - FTP Connection Established and File Export Event Detected
OAT: Multiple service stop events on Linux.
OAT: Multiple Disable of Linux Services.
OAT: High Number of User Windows Account Deleted
OAT: Windows: User Account Creation and Deletion within 15 Minutes
OAT: Multiple critical services stopped on Windows servers.
OAT: Multiple Windows-File Folder Permission Changes.
OAT: Multiple Users Deletion Event Detected - Linux
OAT: Repeated Login Attempts Detected by same account
OAT: Multiple Windows Password Change event detected in One Day
OAT: Environment probing (System Owner/User Discovery) has been detected
OAT: Detection avoidance by impairing defenses (Disable or Modify Tools)
OAT: Suspicious Activity: Netcat Listener on Port 80 and Local User Discovery.
OAT: Detecting Multiple Password Changes by the Same User Within 24 Hours
OAT: PowerView.ps1 Download and Execution from Temp Folder
OAT: LSASS Extraction via Minidump Module and 7zip Compression Detection
OAT: Delete Event Logs Using Wevutil Command
OAT: Potential system control modifications with suspicious process execution detected.
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule identifies a sequence of suspicious activities including process creation and system modification events. The pattern involves modification of system controls followed by execution of suspicious processes, potentially indicating attempts to establish persistence through registry modifications and binary execution.

rule.description: OAT: Malicious email phishing activity detection.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects potential phishing attempts through email communications. These social engineering attempts often include deceptive content, malicious attachments, or links designed to harvest credentials or deliver malware.

rule.description: OAT: Phishing email artifacts leading to credential harvesting activity observed.
rule.info: 106781: OAT: Suspicious email attachment with executable content detected. 106782: Credential capture activity followed by persistence mechanism detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a sequence where malicious email attachments are followed by credential harvesting attempts. This pattern indicates a potential successful phishing attack leading to credential theft activities.

rule.description: OAT: Multiple failed logons attempts followed by a successful logon within an hour.
OAT: Unix - FTP connection established with file transfer import and export event detected.
OAT: Email-delivered malware with known malicious patterns identified.
rule.info: 106784: OAT: Malicious email campaign indicators observed. 106785: OAT: Malicious file pattern signature match detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a sequence where suspicious email delivery is followed by detection of known malicious file patterns. This indicates a successful phishing attack resulting in malware deployment.

rule.description: OAT: Multi-stage attack combining system encryption and credential theft detected.
rule.info: 106795: OAT: Restore Point deletion and encryption activity detected. 106793: OAT: credential extraction tool and memory dumping detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a sophisticated attack combining ransomware preparation activities (encryption setup and recovery deletion) with credential theft attempts. This pattern indicates a complex attack trying to both compromise data and gather credentials for further lateral movement.

rule.description: OAT: Ajax team breach activity detected.
rule.info: 106787: OAT: Email-delivered malware with known malicious patterns identified. 106786: OAT: Suspicious DLL loading through system utility detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a complete attack chain starting from phishing email delivery, followed by malicious file presence, and culminating in suspicious DLL execution through system utilities. This sequence indicates successful exploitation through social engineering.

rule.description: OAT: Ransomware attack chain with credential theft and file encryption confirmed.
rule.info: 106796: OAT: Multi-stage attack combining system encryption and credential theft detected. 106789: OAT: Ransomware-related file pattern extension modification detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a complete ransomware attack sequence including system recovery tampering, credential theft, and active file encryption. This pattern indicates final stages of ransomware deployment where file encryption is actively occurring after initial compromise steps.

rule.description: OAT: Potential "AKIRA" ransomeware detected.
rule.info: 106797: OAT: Ransomware attack chain with credential theft and file encryption confirmed. 106794: OAT: Data transfer utility execution detected. Description: This correlation rule identifies a complete attack sequence involving ransomware deployment, credential theft, and data exfiltration attempts. This sophisticated pattern indicates a double-extortion ransomware attack where data is both encrypted and stolen.
